{"abstract": "SHOELESS IN RENO? Unisys plans to open its first Registered Traveler program kiosk at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport in mid-February. But it is unlikely that the program will initially offer shoe-scanning technology, said Larry Zmuda, the company\u2019s partner for homeland-security-related business. In an interview, Mr. Zmuda said the major concern for Unisys was ensuring the program\u2019s \u201cpredictability\u201d for members, who will undergo a federal background check and pay an annual fee to receive biometrically encoded I.D. cards and access to a special lane for expedited passage through the security checkpoint. Mr. Zmuda cited early snags with shoe-scanning technology being tested in Orlando by Verified Identity Pass, which already operates a Registered Traveler program called Clear at Orlando and four other airports. The Clear shoe-scanning technology, developed by General Electric Security, was intended to detect traces of explosives and suspicious metal, and to allow most travelers to pass through Clear lanes without having to remove their shoes. But the scanner rejected an unexpectedly high number of travelers\u2019 shoes in Orlando, requiring members to remove their shoes just as they would at regular checkpoints. Mr. Zmuda said Unisys, which plans to be operating in 6 to 10 airports within a year, will probably offer only a special lane for the I.D. cards in Reno while the company continues to study options that will provide more benefits. Steven Brill, the founder of Verified Identity, has said that not having to remove shoes is the biggest potential benefit sought by customers. But Mr. Zmuda said that \u201call of our survey data\u201d show that not having to remove laptops from cases is the biggest benefit sought by potential members.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/30/business/30memo.html", "snippet": "SHOELESS IN RENO? Unisys plans to open its first Registered Traveler program kiosk at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport in mid-February. {"abstract": "General Electric\u2018s chief executive, Jeffery Immelt, received $17.9 million in compensation last year, according to a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. {"abstract": "After several rounds of negotiations, General Electric said Friday that it will buy Sanyo Electric Credit, the financing affiliate of struggling electronics maker Sanyo, in a transaction that could top out at 135 billion yen ($1.14 billion). {"abstract": " It seems that John F. Welch Jr.\u2019s dream of becoming a newspaper baron will have to wait. Speaking before an audience at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the former chairman of General Electric said Thursday that The New York Times Company has made it clear that the Boston Globe is not for sale. Last year, Mr. Welch expressed an interest in buying The Globe, and he joined with Jack Connors, co-founder of Boston advertising agency Hill Holliday, to explore making an offer. But the Times Company has repeatedly said that The Globe is not on the block, and Mr. Welch appears to have gotten the message. markets as varied as prime-time TV and commercial finance, General Electric\u2019s mammoth project along the Hudson River north of Albany is staggering. {"abstract": "With Dow Jones & Company set to become part of Rupert Murdoch\u2019s media empire, Gannett is sometimes touted as the next potential takeover target in the newspaper industry. But it is so huge \u2014 with a market capitalization of nearly $11 billion \u2014 that it is hard to imagine who the acquirer would be. Jon Morton, a newspaper analyst, told The New York Times in June that only a big, non-media buyer \u2014 he mentioned General Electric or a buyout firm \u2014 could possibly do such a deal, and even that\u2019s unlikely. {"abstract": "Frustration with the speed with which concert tickets sell out, only to be offered by resellers at a higher price, has led to several investigations by state attorneys general.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/06/business/06money.html", "snippet": "Frustration with the speed with which concert tickets sell out, only to be offered by resellers at a higher price, has led to several investigations by state attorneys general.", "lead_paragraph": "LISA SENAUKE, a Bruce Springsteen fan since 1973, tried to get tickets to his Oct. 26 concert in Oakland, Calif. The tickets were to go on sale at 10 a.m. on Sept. 17, and starting at 9:58 a.m., she logged into her Ticketmaster.com account, credit card in hand. {"abstract": "The General Electric shoe-scanning machine, rejected by the government, was supposed to enable airline passengers to pass through security with their shoes on.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/10/business/10shoe.html", "snippet": "The General Electric shoe-scanning machine, rejected by the government, was supposed to enable airline passengers to pass through security with their shoes on.", "lead_paragraph": "You will still have to take your shoes off at the airport checkpoint. The Transportation Security Administration said yesterday that it had rejected the use of a General Electric shoe-scanning machine that was supposed to provide a central benefit for members of the Clear version of the Registered Traveler program: the ability to pass through security with their shoes on. The machine would instead have scanned the shoes electronically for weapons or explosives.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "7", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "U.S. Again Rejects a Shoe Scanner", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "U.S. Again Rejects A Shoe Scanner", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Security and Warning Systems", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Transportation Security Administration", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "AIRPORTS", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "General Electric Co", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2007-10-10T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Joe Sharkey", "person": [{"firstname": "Joe", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Sharkey", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/1c0cfb78-088c-5784-9917-4cbbb082cb5b", "word_count": 240, "uri": "nyt://article/1c0cfb78-088c-5784-9917-4cbbb082cb5b"}

{"abstract": "L.E.D.\u2019s have replaced standard bulbs in many of the nation\u2019s traffic lights. The bright, long-lasting bulbs are starting to show up in some high-profile places too.", "lead_paragraph": "When the Sentry Equipment Corporation in Oconomowoc, Wis., was considering how to light its new factory last year, the company\u2019s president, Michael Farrell, decided to try something new: light emitting diodes, or L.E.D.\u2019s. {"abstract": "General Electric has repeatedly insisted that NBC Universal isn\u2019t for sale. But engaging in a bit of speculative whimsy, Jack Flack helps the conglomerate game out just how it should go about trying to sell the network-and-movie-studio unit.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2008/08/25/gaming-out-a-hypothetical-nbc-sale/", "snippet": "General Electric has repeatedly insisted that NBC Universal isn\u2019t for sale. But engaging in a bit of speculative whimsy, Jack Flack helps the conglomerate game out just how it should go about trying to sell the network-and-movie-studio unit.", "lead_paragraph": "Despite his protests to the contrary, no one seems to believe General Electric\u2018s Jeffrey Immelt when he says he has no plans to sell NBC Universal. As Jack Flack notes, the conglomerate\u2019s chief sounds a close-to-Shermanesque note in his 2007 letter to investors (PDF): \u201cI just don\u2019t see it happening \u2026 not before the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games \u2026 not after the Olympic Games. {"abstract": "The New York attorney general\u2019s office is concerned that Arbitron does not plan to put devices that measure radio audiences in the hands of enough minority listeners.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/10/business/10arbitron.html", "snippet": "The New York attorney general\u2019s office is concerned that Arbitron does not plan to put devices that measure radio audiences in the hands of enough minority listeners.", "lead_paragraph": "The New York attorney general\u2019s office said Tuesday that it was opening an investigation into the way that Arbitron, which measures audiences for radio stations, is deploying devices called personal people meters.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "New York Investigates a Yardstick for Radio", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "New York Investigates A Yardstick For Radio", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "glocations", "value": "New York State", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Radio", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Minorities (US)", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "ARBITRON INCORPORATED", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Attorneys General", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2008-09-09T23:30:13+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Brian Stelter", "person": [{"firstname": "Brian", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Stelter", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/7e1278a5-b00b-5eed-92b1-bb0396842f1e", "word_count": 551, "uri": "nyt://article/7e1278a5-b00b-5eed-92b1-bb0396842f1e"}

[{"abstract": "Webdenda.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/02/business/media/02adnewsletter3.html", "snippet": "Webdenda.", "lead_paragraph": "Maryam Banikarim joined NBC Universal, New York, part of the General Electric Company, in a new post, senior vice president for integrated sales. What spurred my column this week was the company\u2019s decision to cut its dividend last Friday by 66 percent. But hell week it certainly was. Two analysts at a small firm came out with a brutal report essentially predicting the kind of downward spiral that has so badly damaged other big firms, like Citi and Bank of America. Other bears circled. Credit default spreads widened. The stock sank. The chief financial officer went on CNBC to defend the company. And on and on it went, a dance we\u2019ve seen again and again \u2014 usually with bad results.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Is General Electric Next?", "kicker": "Executive Suite", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2009-03-07T02:53:51+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Joe Nocera", "person": [{"firstname": "Joe", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Nocera", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/32ef2c31-5d76-5c01-a30a-2b5f217a18a2", "word_count": 313, "uri": "nyt://article/32ef2c31-5d76-5c01-a30a-2b5f217a18a2"}]

{"abstract": "General Electric, which lost its AAA rating Thursday, had maintained a high overall rating until now because of the steady cash thrown off by the industrial side of its business.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/13/business/13views.html", "snippet": "General Electric, which lost its AAA rating Thursday, had maintained a high overall rating until now because of the steady cash thrown off by the industrial side of its business.", "lead_paragraph": "General Electric finally lost its AAA rating. This shouldn\u2019t affect the company\u2019s financing costs, since the markets have ignored the rating for some time. But the conglomerate\u2019s top rating was a big reason for keeping its industrial and financial arms together. The strength of the industrial business theoretically allowed the financial arm to raise debt cheaply, allowing it to thrive. The downgrade guts this rationale. {"abstract": "G.E. said it had not yet selected a location for the plant, which will employ 400 workers and manufacture thin-film photovoltaic panels beginning in 2013.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/07/business/energy-environment/07electric.html", "snippet": "G.E. said it had not yet selected a location for the plant, which will employ 400 workers and manufacture thin-film photovoltaic panels beginning in 2013.", "lead_paragraph": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 In a move that could shake up the American solar industry, General Electric plans to announce on Thursday that it will build the nation\u2019s largest photovoltaic panel factory, with the goal of becoming a major player in the market. {"abstract": "David Einhorn\u2019s critique of Steve Ballmer is on target even if he\u2019s far from the only chief executive who has struggled to make the most of a franchise.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/30/business/economy/30views.html", "snippet": "David Einhorn\u2019s critique of Steve Ballmer is on target even if he\u2019s far from the only chief executive who has struggled to make the most of a franchise.", "lead_paragraph": "Microsoft has missed too many opportunities under Steve Ballmer\u2019s stewardship. {"abstract": "General Electric will team up with Cinelan to make 30 three-minute films by well-known directors, including Morgan Spurlock.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/g-e-to-produce-short-films-about-innovation/", "snippet": "General Electric will team up with Cinelan to make 30 three-minute films by well-known directors, including Morgan Spurlock.", "lead_paragraph": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 General Electric just can\u2019t stay away from the movies. Barely eight months after ceding control of NBC Universal and its Universal Studios to Comcast, G.E. is diving into the documentary world as the financial backer of 30 three-minute films by directors including Morgan Spurlock (\u201cPOM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold\u201d), Joe Berlinger (\u201cCrude\u201d), Barbara Kopple (\u201cShut Up and Sing\u201d) and Alex Gibney (\u201cMagic Trip: Ken Kesey\u2019s Search for a Kool Place\u201d).", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "G.E. to Produce Short Films About Innovation", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Documentary Films and Programs", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Movies", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Spurlock, Morgan", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "General Electric Company", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-08-28T20:54:01+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Michael Cieply", "person": [{"firstname": "Michael", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cieply", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/1c296ca9-fe48-59cd-9158-eb8588caf61c", "word_count": 363, "uri": "nyt://article/1c296ca9-fe48-59cd-9158-eb8588caf61c"}

{"abstract": "Nevada\u2019s attorney general wants to end a broad mortgage agreement it struck with Bank of America in 2008.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/31/business/bank-of-america-accused-of-breaching-mortgage-accord.html", "snippet": "Nevada\u2019s attorney general wants to end a broad mortgage agreement it struck with Bank of America in 2008.", "lead_paragraph": "The attorney general of Nevada is accusing Bank of America of repeatedly violating a broad loan modification agreement it struck with state officials in October 2008 and is seeking to rip up the deal so that the state can proceed with a suit against the bank over allegations of deceptive lending, marketing and loan servicing practices. {"abstract": "General Electric intends to buy back $3 billion of preferred stock from Warren E. Buffett, an indication of the company\u2019s financial rebound.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/14/business/for-ge-repaying-buffett-looks-good-breakingviews.html", "snippet": "General Electric intends to buy back $3 billion of preferred stock from Warren E. Buffett, an indication of the company\u2019s financial rebound.", "lead_paragraph": "When Warren E. Buffett invests in companies like General Electric or Goldman Sachs, markets almost always interpret it as a great vote of confidence. But is it not an even more positive signal when those same companies, returned to health and flush with abundant profits, pay him back? If so, then investors might want to use G.E.\u2019s decision to return Mr. Buffett\u2019s money \u2014 which served as a life raft to the company during the 2008 crisis \u2014 to reflect on just how much better off the American financial system has become.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Repaying Buffett Has Its Upside", "kicker": "Reuters Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Repaying Buffett Has Its Upside", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "persons", "value": "Buffett, Warren E", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Profumo, Alessandro", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "General Electric Company", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Italy", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-09-19T19:16:37+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By ROB COX, AGNEST T. {"abstract": "The practice of exchanging one asset for another without incurring taxes has spread to major corporations from the family farmers the tax break was intended to help.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/07/business/economy/companies-exploit-tax-break-for-asset-exchanges-trial-evidence-shows.html", "snippet": "The practice of exchanging one asset for another without incurring taxes has spread to major corporations from the family farmers the tax break was intended to help.", "lead_paragraph": "It began more than 90 years ago as a small tax break intended to help family farmers who wanted to swap horses and land. [{"abstract": "Comcast bought the rest of NBCUniversal from General Electric for $16.7 billion; Web sites that help uncover new books, like Goodreads.com, have become indispensable for readers, writers and publishers; and Slacker, a digital music service, takes aim at Pandora in new advertisements.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/13/the-breakfast-meeting-comcast-buys-rest-of-nbcuniversal-and-sites-that-appeal-to-book-lovers/", "snippet": "Comcast bought the rest of NBCUniversal from General Electric for $16.7 billion; Web sites that help uncover new books, like Goodreads.com, have become indispensable for readers, writers and publishers; and Slacker, a digital music service, takes ...", "lead_paragraph": "9:28 a.m. | Updated Comcast agreed to pay General Electric $16.7 billion to acquire their remaining 49 percent stake in NBCUniversal on Tuesday, Amy Chozick and Brian Stelter write. Brian Roberts, Comcast\u2019s chief executive, said that the acquisition was a necessary step given the rapidly changing television business and the necessity of owning content. Comcast bought a 51 percent share in NBCUniversal in early 2011, with the option of buying the rest of the company over the next seven years; the process was accelerated at least in part by a clash in corporate cultures between G.E. and Comcast. The deal will also include 30 Rockefeller Plaza and the CNBC headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., for about $1.4 billion. Naming rights are included in the deal, so the red G.E. sign atop 30 Rockefeller Plaza could be replaced with a Comcast logo.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Comcast Buys Rest of NBCUniversal, and Sites That Appeal to Book Lovers", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2013-02-13T14:11:39+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Daniel E. {"abstract": "Still, in designating A.I.G. and GE Capital systemically important, regulators show they are stuck for the most part in the last crisis rather than looking out for the next one, the author contends.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/06/04/better-late-than-never-on-nonbank-too-big-to-fail/", "snippet": "Still, in designating A.I.G. and GE Capital systemically important, regulators show they are stuck for the most part in the last crisis rather than looking out for the next one, the author contends.", "lead_paragraph": "New systemic-risk tags are better late than never. The American International Group, GE Capital and Prudential Financial are among the first nonbank firms to be deemed systemically important financial institutions by the Financial Stability Oversight Council. These are no-brainers for the moniker. The trouble is, five years on, watchdogs are still bogged down in the last crisis rather than looking out for the next one.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Better Late Than Never on Deeming Nonbanks Too Big to Fail", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Regulation and Deregulation of Industry", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "GE Capital Corp", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Prudential Financial Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Treasury Department", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-06-04T22:36:36+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Agnes T. {"abstract": "A loan package to a little-known company highlights a new credit boom taking shape. | Business development companies are suddenly hot, but they come with risks. | A former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors agreed to testify against his onetime boss in a bid to avoid jail time. | Men\u2019s Wearhouse turned the tables on Jos. A. Bank.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/11/27/morning-agenda-a-new-credit-boom/", "snippet": "A loan package to a little-known company highlights a new credit boom taking shape. | Business development companies are suddenly hot, but they come with risks. | A former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors agreed to testify against his onetime boss ...", "lead_paragraph": "A $330 million loan package to a small, little-known company from Missouri highlights how a new credit boom is taking shape, five years after the bubble, Lynnley Browning reports in DealBook. The company, Learfield Communications, of Jefferson City, Mo., owns multimedia rights to more than four dozen college sports programs and made just under $40 million last year in a common measure of earnings. It borrowed the money from Deutsche Bank and GE Capital on Oct. 9. Though the loans were rated subprime, with few of the standard protections seen in ordinary debt, investors clamored to buy pieces of the loans, one of which pays annual interest of at least 8.75 percent.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "A New Credit Boom", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2013-11-27T13:09:20+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By William Alden", "person": [{"firstname": "William", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Alden", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/387acfb5-781a-5119-b88f-62b4a538c3d5", "word_count": 2035, "uri": "nyt://article/387acfb5-781a-5119-b88f-62b4a538c3d5"}

{"abstract": "The post-recession reality is that the customer base for businesses that appeal to the middle class is shrinking as the top tier pulls even further away.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/03/business/the-middle-class-is-steadily-eroding-just-ask-the-business-world.html", "snippet": "The post-recession reality is that the customer base for businesses that appeal to the middle class is shrinking as the top tier pulls even further away.", "lead_paragraph": "In Manhattan, the upscale clothing retailer Barneys will replace the bankrupt discounter Loehmann\u2019s, whose Chelsea store closes in a few weeks. Across the country, Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants are struggling, while fine-dining chains like Capital Grille are thriving. Icahn in 2010.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/03/14/morning-agenda-s-e-c-takes-aim-at-another-former-sac-employee/", "snippet": "The S.E.C. unveiled a civil case against a 10th former SAC Capital employee. | An internal investigation found that the Justice Department had repeatedly and significantly overstated its efforts to prosecute mortgage fraud. | G.E. filed to spin of...", "lead_paragraph": "S.E.C. TAKES AIM AT 10TH FORMER SAC EMPLOYEE \u00a0|\u00a0 The Securities and Exchange Commission\u2019s investigation into Steven A. Cohen\u2019s hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, isn\u2019t done just yet. Federal regulators announced on Thursday a civil case against Ronald N. Dennis, who worked for SAC for less than two years, for prompting a number of illegal trades stemming from confidential tips he received about two technology companies, Dell and Foundry Networks, Ben Protess and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Dennis, the 10th former employee of SAC to face civil or criminal insider trading charges, settled with the S.E.C., agreeing to be banned from the securities industry and to pay $200,000.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "S.E.C. {"abstract": "The approval of the $13.5 billion deal essentially brings the long acquisition negotiations to an end, though a final deal hinges on the French state buying Alstom shares.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/06/21/alstom-board-backs-offer-from-g-e-bringing-final-deal-in-sight/", "snippet": "The approval of the $13.5 billion deal essentially brings the long acquisition negotiations to an end, though a final deal hinges on the French state buying Alstom shares.", "lead_paragraph": "PARIS \u2014 The board of the French industrial conglomerate Alstom said Saturday that it had unanimously backed General Electric\u2019s offer to acquire most of its energy business for $13.5 billion, essentially ending the battle for the company. A final deal was still awaiting the successful outcome of negotiations between the government and Alstom\u2019s largest shareholder over the sale of a stake to the state.", "print_section": "A", {"abstract": "The Serious Fraud Office said it had charged Alstom Network UK with six corruption-related offenses linked to contracts in India, Tunisia and Poland.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/25/business/international/britain-brings-corruption-charges-against-unit-of-alstom.html", "snippet": "The Serious Fraud Office said it had charged Alstom Network UK with six corruption-related offenses linked to contracts in India, Tunisia and Poland.", "lead_paragraph": "PARIS \u2014 British authorities said on Thursday that they had brought criminal charges against a unit of Alstom, the French industrial conglomerate that is selling its energy business to General Electric. {"abstract": "Regulators are pushing for changes that will affect derivatives. | G.E. is in talks to sell its appliances unit. | Coca-Cola announced that it had acquired a stake in Monster Beverage. | Bitcoin\u2019s pop may exceed its potential.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/08/15/morning-agenda-tension-mounts-over-derivatives/", "snippet": "Regulators are pushing for changes that will affect derivatives. | G.E. is in talks to sell its appliances unit. | Coca-Cola announced that it had acquired a stake in Monster Beverage. | Bitcoin\u2019s pop may exceed its potential.", "lead_paragraph": "TENSION MOUNTS OVER DERIVATIVES | Financial regulators are pushing for an arcane but crucial modification to the contracts that stand behind the $700 trillion global market for derivatives as part of their efforts to avoid the sort of systemic chaos that occurred after Lehman Brothers crashed in 2008, DealBook\u2019s Peter Eavis writes. Wall Street is largely resigned to the regulators\u2019 ultimately getting their way, but it is nevertheless pressing for measures seen as protections in return.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Tension Mounts Over Derivatives", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-08-15T11:42:09+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/0bd4ff7a-04d3-55bf-972c-202df19954ac", "word_count": 1923, "uri": "nyt://article/0bd4ff7a-04d3-55bf-972c-202df19954ac"}

{"abstract": "An executive of Mondelez International, which ran a spot featuring nontraditional families, said, \u201cBeing fearless is the only answer right now.\u201d", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/01/business/media/advertising-week-marketers-are-urged-to-become-fearless.html", "snippet": "An executive of Mondelez International, which ran a spot featuring nontraditional families, said, \u201cBeing fearless is the only answer right now.\u201d", "lead_paragraph": "IT is rare on Madison Avenue to hear, at least publicly, suggestions that executives are scaredy-cats who are afraid to take risks. {"abstract": "General Electric has been a beehive of activity, but the market thinks its shares are dead money, and such a perception may be difficult to shake off.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/18/business/dealbook/if-only-ge-had-an-activist-investor-who-cared.html", "snippet": "General Electric has been a beehive of activity, but the market thinks its shares are dead money, and such a perception may be difficult to shake off.", "lead_paragraph": "Almost nothing General Electric does registers with its stockholders. A big asset sale? Shares hardly budge. A multibillion-dollar acquisition? Yawn. Aggressive shrinkage of its irritating financial business? Crickets. It seems investors no longer care about the company, a $254 billion conglomerate run by Jeffrey R. Immelt. If only G.E. had an activist who cared.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "If Only G.E. {"abstract": "Powerful Republicans are bent on letting the export credit agency die, imperiling overseas projects and sales by American companies.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/21/business/international/threat-to-us-export-import-bank-imperils-a-water-project-in-cameroon.html", "snippet": "Powerful Republicans are bent on letting the export credit agency die, imperiling overseas projects and sales by American companies.", "lead_paragraph": "WASHINGTON \u2014 In 2013, the impoverished African nation Cameroon teamed with General Electric and the Environmental Chemical Corporation, which is based in Burlingame, Calif., to begin work on a $668 million drinking water project for its thirsty capital, financed with loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank of the United States. {"abstract": "The drumroll is over. This week, the Federal Reserve will most likely announce that it will raise its benchmark interest rate. And Wall Street thinks \u201cThe Force Awakens\u201d will deliver a huge opening.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/14/business/fed-expected-to-raise-rate-and-high-expectations-for-new-star-wars.html", "snippet": "The drumroll is over. And Wall Street thinks \u201cThe Force Awakens\u201d will deliver a huge opening.", "lead_paragraph": "On Tuesday, the Labor Department is expected to release its latest update on changes in consumer prices for November. With the continuing plunge in oil prices \u2014 average pump prices dropped 19 cents in just one month \u2014 and widespread discounting in sectors from apparel to cars last month, analysts expect the Consumer Price Index to remain flat. Even a drop in the headline number is unlikely to push the Federal Reserve off course and deter it from raising the benchmark interest rate when it meets on Wednesday. \u2014Patricia Cohen", {"abstract": "Companies like G.E. are working with podcast networks to produce original series \u2014 a kind of twist on \u201cnative ads\u201d that are crafted to resemble editorial content.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/21/business/media/marketers-make-the-podcasts.html", "snippet": "Companies like G.E. are working with podcast networks to produce original series \u2014 a kind of twist on \u201cnative ads\u201d that are crafted to resemble editorial content.", "lead_paragraph": "FOR a brand seeking to reach the podcast-listening public, there is one thing better than sponsoring a hit series: creating your own.
